abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Industrial Technology (Spark)
            Project for China achieved mixed results. The technical
            assistance components are rated highly satisfactory, while
            the enterprise modernization component is rated highly
            unsatisfactory. Likewise, sustainability is rated as likely
            for all technical assistance components, but uncertain for
            the enterprise modernization component. The Bank's
            performance is rated as satisfactory. Bank staff provided
            effective support and advice. However, additional staff
            resources were needed. Borrower performance is rated as
            satisfactory. The report notes excellent management,
            coordination, and communication of results. Overall, the
            project's simultaneous focus on multiple target groups,
            government entities, enterprises, and financial institutions
            in various localities made the project very complex and
            difficult to manage. Also, the substantial delay between
            project appraisal in 1998 and project effectiveness in 1991
            led to poor performance by the initial batch of subprojects.
            There are six main lessons learned. First, successful
            execution of technical assistance requires the full
            commitment of all stakeholders throughout the process.
            Second, national ownership is important. In this case, Spark
            is a national program and the Bank is perceived as a helper.
            Third, sound organizational setup and dynamic leadership are
            essential to project success. Fourth, the Bank's
            project supervision missions must be better staffed with
            technical staff and consultants. Fifth, while financial
            institutions must improve their expertise in subproject
            evaluation, the Bank must recognize that enterprises still
            face many constraints under the current national policy
            framework. Finally, for lines of credit operations using
            financial intermediaries to be successful, basic structural
            changes in the financial and enterprise sectors are needed.
